sen.j: 地下家（じげけ）は、昇殿が許されない廷臣の家格。
sen.e: Jigeke was a family status of court officials which were not permitted to enter the Courtiers' Hall in the Imperial Palace.

sen.j: 昇殿とは天皇の日常生活の場である清涼殿南廂にある殿上へ昇ることで、平安時代は家格・官位に関係なく、廷臣ごとに勅許を得ることでこれを許されていた。
sen.e: Entering the Courtiers' Hall in the Imperial Palace' means entering the Courtiers' Hall called Tenjo No Ma in the emperor's private living quarters, i.e., in the south side of the emperor's residence Seiryoden; and during the Heian period, court officials were authorized by imperial sanction to enter the Hall without regard for their family rank and court rank.

sen.j: しかしながら、中世以降は昇殿を許される家（堂上家）と昇殿を許されない家（地下家）として、家格で明確に区分されるようになり成立した。
sen.e: After the Medieval Ages, the status Jigeke was established when the court officials were clearly divided according to their family rank, and the families permitted to enter the Hall were called Toshoke, and the families not permitted to enter the Hall were called Jigeke.

sen.j: 従って、地下家の廷臣は三位に昇っても昇殿は許されなかった。
sen.e: Accordingly, the court officials from Jigeke were not permitted to enter the Hall, even if their official rank was raised to Third Rank.

sen.j: また、六位蔵人は地下人であっても昇殿が許され、その中でもっとも上位である極臈を1代で3度務めるか、3代連続で務めた家は堂上家となる例があったが実例は少ない。
sen.e: Yet, although chamberlains of Sixth Rank were low-ranking court officials called Jigenin, they were permitted to enter the Hall; besides, there were cases--though a few cases--that when the chamberlain of six rank served as the highest ranked chamberlain called 'gokuro' three times in his lifetime, or a family of the chamberlain of six rank produced the highest ranked chamberlain for three successive generations, they were raised to Toshoke.

sen.j: なお、堂上家と同様旧家・新家の区分があったが、桜町天皇（在位1735年 - 1747年）の時代にみだりに新家を立てることが停止された。
sen.e: Other than the division into Toshoke and Jigeke, there were another division of families into Kyuka (the families with long family genealogy) and Shinke (the families established around the Edo period); however, during the reign of Emperor Sakuramachi (reigned 1735-1747), it was banned to establish a new family without permission.

sen.j: 明治維新後、地下家の筆頭格であった押小路家・壬生家は堂上家に準じて、また、伊丹家（伊丹重賢：青蓮院諸大夫）・尾崎家（尾崎三良：三条家諸大夫）・富井家（富井政章：聖護院坊官）は勲功により華族（男爵）に列せられた。
sen.e: After the Meiji Restoration, the title of Danshaku (Baron - one of the titles of Kazoku (nobility)), was given to the Oshikoji family (or the Oshinokoji family) and the Mibu family, which were the leading Jigeke, correspondingly to raise them to Toshoke; and the Itami family (Shigekata ITAMI: court official served at Shorenin Temple), the Ozaki family (Saburo OZAKI: court official served at the Sanjo family), and the Tomii family (Masaakira Tomii: a senior servant at Shogoin Temple) in recognition of merit.

sen.j: だが、押小路家・壬生家の両家に次ぐ蔵人所出納の平田家以下、ほとんどの地下家は原則として士族として扱われた。
sen.e: Primarily, however, the treatment of Shizoku (the family of samurai descendants) was applied to most families of Jigeke, including the Hirata family which served as a secretary at the Bureau of Archivists and ranked next to the Oshikoji family and the Mibu family in Jigeke.

sen.j: 地下家も堂上家と同様、世職世業であった。
sen.e: Like those of Toshoke, offices and businesses of Jigeke were hereditary.

sen.j: 江戸時代には地下の世職は局務（外記上首：押小路家が世襲）・官務（左大史上首：壬生家が世襲）・蔵人所出納（平田家が世襲）が、それぞれ外記方・官方・蔵人方の世襲の諸役人を管掌し、朝廷の各種行事の運営を司った（催官人）。
sen.e: During the Edo period, the hereditary officials from Jigeke--the Head of Secretaries 'Kyokumu' (the leader of secretaries in the Council of State Secretaries, inherited by the Oshinokoji family), the Head of Secretaries 'Kanmu' (the leader of Senior Recorders of the Left, inherited by the Mibu family), and the court official at the Bureau of Archivists 'Kurodo dokoro Suino' (inherited by the Hirata family)--were collectively called 'Saikanjin' and respectively managed events and ceremonies of the Imperial Court by supervising the hereditary officials of secretaries, recorders, and staff of the Bureau of Archivists.

sen.j: 催官人の3家以外の地下家の官人は、並官人と呼ばれ、更にその下には儀式などの際に雑用を担当する下官人と呼ばれる人々がいた。
sen.e: Other than the three families called Saikanjin, the court officials from Jigeke were called Namikanjin (general court officials) and had subordinates called Shimokanjin, who did heavy labor for the events and ceremonies.

sen.e: Generally, Namikanjin rose from Sixth Rank, whereas Shimokanjin rose from Seventh Rank or Shisho (lower-ranked officials).

sen.j: 下官人は一種の「株」の形で身分を売買することが行われ（表面上は買主が売主の養子縁組に入る場合が多い）、また必要な人員確保を理由とした官司による取立も行われたため、京都や周辺の商人や農民が社会的身分の上昇や生活の糧（仕事）の獲得などを目的に地下官人の身分を得る例もあった（催官人は官司からの地下人補任の申請があれば、ほとんどの場合そのまま受理していた）。
sen.e: The rank of Shimokanjin was traded in the form of 'stock' ostensibly through adoption of 'the buyer' by 'the seller' in most cases, and sometimes 'collected' by the government office on the pretext of staff acquisition, which led some cases of merchants and farmers in Kyoto and its surroundings acquiring the rank of Jige official for the purpose of raising their social status or earning their living, i.e., securing their jobs (In most cases, Saikanjin accepted the application for appointment of Jigenin by the government office without question.).

sen.j: 下官人は江戸後期の朝儀再興に伴う人手不足を補うために増員され、『地下次第』によれば延享5年（1746年）には73名であったものが、寛政8年（1796年）には110名、嘉永2年（1849年）には170名に増加している。
sen.e: Shimokanjin was increased to meet the manpower shortage caused by imperial ceremony restoration in the latter half of the Edo period: According to "Jige Shidai" (Records of Jige), they were 73 in 1746, increased to 110 in 1796 and to 170 in 1849.
